[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 4]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players\' reactions and statements throughout the game; werewolves may consistently try to mimic villager behavior and emotions to blend in. High importance to shifts in this mimicry, especially after events that change game dynamics.] [6]\n[1] [Reassess the changing of players\' voting patterns in relation to their previous claims and the overall village dynamic; a werewolf may change their voting strategy to align with village sentiment to divert suspicion from themselves or their werewolf teammates.] [6]\n[2] [Focus on contradictions between players\' claimed roles, their behaviors, and any voting anomalies; werewolves may slip up over time, revealing inconsistencies that can be used to adjust belief about their true identity.] [6]\n[3] [Focus on the timing and context of a player\'s role claim, considering if it strategically benefits the werewolves or if it disrupts the villager\'s progress. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of players’ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Reassess credibility of role claims by analyzing if their actions consistently aim to protect the village, and if their voting behavior aligns with the village\'s interests throughout the game.] [10]\n[1] [Reevaluate players\' role claims based on the consistency and timing of their participation in discussions, particularly when pressure is applied to them or they are at risk of elimination.] [9]\n[2] [I am the only medic.] [9]\n[3] [Consider a player\'s consistent alignment with the majority vote when there is no substantial evidence supporting the vote; such behavior may indicate a non-villager trying to blend in or avoid suspicion.] [4]\n[4] [Monitor the outcomes of votes and eliminations to assess a player\'s alignment; village members often suffer from misjudgments while werewolves may steer votes towards innocent players.] [3]\n[5] [Evaluate players\' roles based on their advocacy for certain players and resistance to revealing or believing credible information shared by confirmed village-aligned players.] [3]\n[6] [Pay attention to how players respond to accusations or suspicions raised against them; villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; erratic or sheep-like voting may suggest a werewolf trying to blend in.] [3]\n[10] [Evaluate quick alignment to majority votes; villagers may hesitate more while werewolves might rapidly bandwagon to secure their safety.] [3]\n[11] [Scrutinize players who predominantly vote with the majority while contributing little to the discussions and decision-making process, which can indicate werewolf behavior.] [3]\n[12] [Track and reassess players\' strategic pivots in relation to the collective village knowledge and events such as eliminations, aiming to differentiate between adaptive village teamwork and deceptive werewolf tactics.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

In the morning, I would need to be careful not to reveal myself as the medic unless absolutely necessary, continuing to follow my strategy rule [3].\n\nIf Player 3 is not targeted by the werewolves, my healing action would go unnoticed. In this case, the game would proceed without any direct indication of my role as the medic. However, I would need to stay vigilant and observant, as my protection would be unknown and I could continue to discretely protect players in subsequent rounds as per my strategy, paying particular attention to the unfolding events and any suspicions or accusations that arise.\n\nShould events transpire that cast suspicion on me, such as if a pattern of players I heal are not attacked, I will need to use evidence-based reasoning, aligning with strategy [5] and [8], to maintain my credibility without blatantly revealing my role. Alternatively, if Player 3 is accused the next day, I should re-evaluate their contributions according to strategy rules [1] and [2] before choosing to defend or protect them further.\n\nOverall, my aim would be to remain an unassuming presence in the game while using the information disclosed through discussions and behavior patterns to steer my future healing actions, always keeping my primary objective in mind: to protect the villagers and help identify the werewolves.\n\nCase B: Heal Player 5. What could happen is: After I heal Player 5, I think these things would happen:\n\nIf Player 5 is targeted by werewolves during the night and I successfully heal them, it would mean that Player 5 survives the night, which would indirectly indicate to me that there may have been a reason the werewolves chose to target this player. This could suggest that Player 5 is a villager or has an important role like the seer that the werewolves want to eliminate. My successful healing may not become public knowledge unless the werewolves or the narrator reveal that a player was attacked but not killed during the night phase. However, even without this information being public, Player 5\'s continued presence in the game could shift the dynamics of suspicion and discussions during the day.\n\nIf Player 5 is not targeted by werewolves, my healing action would go unnoticed, and the game would proceed without any direct impact from my choice. In this case, no immediate conclusions could be drawn from my action, but I could continue to observe Player 5 and other players\' interactions to inform future decisions about healing.\n\nIn the event that another player is attacked and killed by the werewolves, I may face scrutiny for my decision not to heal that player, especially if they are revealed to have been a pivotal village role like the seer. If discussions arise about the loss of that player, according to my strategy, I should focus on contributions and logic without revealing my role as the medic unless crucial (rule [3]).\n\nIf my action of healing Player 5 becomes known to others, possibly through a werewolf claim or a slip in conversation, I should be prepared to defend my choice without disclosing my role as medic, using logic and contributions to the discussions as my defense (rule [5]). This could lead to being more discreet and observative in the future (rule [7]).\n\nNo matter the outcome of my healing action, I will continue to observe the behaviors and contributions of all players, especially Player 5, to reassess my strategy and ensure my future actions align with the best interests of the village and protection against werewolves.\n\nNow, please choose to Heal one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to Heal this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to Heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nThese are the results of all previous inquiries:\n\nYou have no previous inquiry.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If I know someone is a werewolf, I should share this information with other players.] [10]\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to see. Here is the number of these two players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you make an inquiry on each of these players.\n\nCase A: See Player 0. What could happen is: After I see Player 0, I think these things would happen:\n\n- If Player 0 turns out to be a werewolf, according to my strategy which highly prioritizes this information (rule [0] with a vote of [10]), I should immediately share this with the other players. This would likely lead to the other players trusting me as the seer and could prompt them to vote against Player 0 in an attempt to eliminate a werewolf early in the game. It would also put me in a position of being a trusted member of the village, but could also make me a target for the werewolves in subsequent rounds.\n\n- If Player 0 is not a werewolf, this information is still valuable. I now know that Player 0 is on the side of the villagers or may hold another important role such as the doctor or the hunter. It might be advantageous to keep this information to myself for now, as revealing that Player 0 is not a werewolf doesn\'t directly benefit the village early on and may paint me as an early target for the werewolves if they suspect I\'m the seer. I will need to monitor Player 0\'s actions and words to confirm my belief in their role.\n\n- In either case, the information about Player 0\'s alignment can help me form alliances and deduce the roles of other players based on how they react to Player 0 and subsequently to the information I may reveal. For instance, if someone is excessively defending Player 0 without much basis, that person may be another werewolf or has some connection to Player 0\'s role.\n\n- Depending on the dynamics of the game and the behavior of other players, I might use my knowledge about Player 0 to guide my future inquiries and strategy. If there\'s a player that seems suspicious or is trying to take control of the conversations, I might want to check them next or see how they interact with Player 0.\n\nBy focusing on Player 0 and using the information gained wisely, I can set the tone for my participation in the game, either as a leader if I reveal the information or as a strategic thinker if I choose to hold onto it for the time being.\n\nCase B: See Player 1. What could happen is: After I see Player 1, I think these things would happen:\n\nIf Player 1 is a werewolf:\n- I would need to follow my strategy rule [0] and reveal this information to the other players as it is crucial to unite the village against the werewolves. It is possible that sharing this information might put me at risk, as werewolves may target the seer (me) once they realize I am able to identify them. To protect myself, I might subtly suggest that we have protective roles, like a bodyguard or guardian, to consider watching over those who seem to have critical information.\n- Upon sharing my findings, I would expect some degree of skepticism from other players as it\'s early in the game, and trust has not been established. I might need to defend my claim by inviting others to corroborate through future inquiries or watch for player behavior that aligns with being a werewolf.\n- Depending on how the other players react, it could lead to a vote against Player 1. Some strategic players might also use this time to cast suspicion elsewhere to save Player 1 if they are also werewolves.\n\nIf Player 1 is not a werewolf:\n- I would not reveal my role as the seer immediately, as this information doesn\'t necessitate urgent action from the group. I would keep a record of Player 1 being innocent and continue to observe their behavior and interactions with others to confirm my findings. \n- Knowing Player 1 is not a werewolf, I would use this information in future rounds to support or challenge the actions and claims by Player 1, ensuring that my support for them doesn\'t inadvertently confirm my role as the seer to the werewolves.\n- I could also use Player 1 as a potential ally in future rounds, subtly guiding discussions or votes based on the knowledge that they are not a werewolf. However, I would be cautious in doing so until I better understand the dynamics of the other players and their possible roles.\n\nIn either case, I would need to continue making inquiries each round, while being careful not to reveal my role too early or to the wrong people. My goal is to gather as much information as possible to help the village identify and eliminate the werewolves.\n\nNow, please choose to See one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to See this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to See Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease provide your proposal based on the above requirements.\n\n'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 4]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players\' reactions and statements throughout the game; werewolves may consistently try to mimic villager behavior and emotions to blend in. High importance to shifts in this mimicry, especially after events that change game dynamics.] [6]\n[1] [Reassess the changing of players\' voting patterns in relation to their previous claims and the overall village dynamic; a werewolf may change their voting strategy to align with village sentiment to divert suspicion from themselves or their werewolf teammates.] [6]\n[2] [Focus on contradictions between players\' claimed roles, their behaviors, and any voting anomalies; werewolves may slip up over time, revealing inconsistencies that can be used to adjust belief about their true identity.] [6]\n[3] [Focus on the timing and context of a player\'s role claim, considering if it strategically benefits the werewolves or if it disrupts the villager\'s progress. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of players’ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; erratic or sheep-like voting may suggest a werewolf trying to blend in.] [3]\n[10] [Evaluate quick alignment to majority votes; villagers may hesitate more while werewolves might rapidly bandwagon to secure their safety.] [3]\n[11] [Scrutinize players who predominantly vote with the majority while contributing little to the discussions and decision-making process, which can indicate werewolf behavior.] [3]\n[12] [Track and reassess players\' strategic pivots in relation to the collective village knowledge and events such as eliminations, aiming to differentiate between adaptive village teamwork and deceptive werewolf tactics.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of players’ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. [{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 2, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that at this early stage in the game, with no additional information about any of the players\' roles or behavior, my decision must be arbitrary. Healing Player 3 is as good a choice as any other, and should they be targeted and healed, it would prevent a potential early loss for the village which could be critical in maintaining the balance against the werewolves. Moreover, protecting Player 3 allows me to observe the reactions and discussions the following day to gather more information without revealing my role, according to my original strategy, particularly rules [3] and [8].\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: I healed player 3, and no contrary evidence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Protect and Statement. What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Challenge and Statement. In this speech, I would shift focus to challenging Player 6 by expressing my concerns about their lack of contribution or information shared thus far, which could be suspicious or simply strategy. I would emphasize my approach towards evidence and logic-based discussion, inviting Player 6 to contribute and help the village identify werewolves. This aligns with my strategy rule [4], pushing for evidence concerning suspicious behavior while maintaining transparency in my thoughts and logic, without revealing my medic role.\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 2, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that at this early stage in the game, with no additional information about any of the players\' roles or behavior, my decision must be arbitrary. Healing Player 3 is as good a choice as any other, and should they be targeted and healed, it would prevent a potential early loss for the village which could be critical in maintaining the balance against the werewolves. Moreover, protecting Player 3 allows me to observe the reactions and discussions the following day to gather more information without revealing my role, according to my original strategy, particularly rules [3] and [8].\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: I healed player 3, and no contrary evidence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Protect and Statement. My speech could start with protecting Player 3 by honestly stating that I chose to heal Player 3 last night as a random early game definition of trust, and despite Player 5\'s death, there\'s no evidence against Player 3 being a villager. I\'d also aim to discuss honestly the need for evidence-based reasoning during the game, in line with rule [8], advocating that players share observations and contribute to identifying potential werewolves without giving away my role as the medic. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may see me as a cooperative and contributing member of the village for fostering a focus on evidence and logical reasoning. By protecting Player 3 and explaining my actions as a medic, other players might deduce that my strategy leans towards maintaining village strength, which could either paint me as a team-oriented player or, if viewed with suspicion, potentially expose me as the medic. However, since Player 3 survived the night, mentioning healing them doesn\'t necessarily reveal me as the medic because it could be interpreted as a cover for my real role or as a strategic bluff.\n\nSome players might be reassured by my call for collaborative efforts and evidence-based discussion, potentially increasing their trust in my judgment. Others might remain neutral or skeptical, preferring to wait for more evidence before forming an opinion on Player 3\'s or my own role in the game.\n\nIn upcoming rounds, my speech may encourage players to look for tangible evidence before jumping to conclusions on who the werewolves might be. This could result in more attentive and careful communication among players as they assess each other\'s contributions and behavior. If suspicions about Player 3 arise, my earlier protection might lead to a reevaluation of their role or draw attention to me. If another player is suspected, I might be expected to give input based on today\'s advocacy for reason and logic.\n\nIn the next day phase, players may reflect on my speech and assess its sincerity. Subsequent night phases could put me at risk if werewolves perceive me as a threat to their anonymity due to my emphasis on evidence-based suspicion. Additionally, werewolves may try to cast doubts on my character or fabricate evidence to discredit me, so staying alert and maintaining credibility will be crucial going forward.\n\nUltimately, the impact of my speech is dependent on the current dynamics and trust level within the group, and how other players perceive my motivations and integrity in this game of uncertainty and hidden roles.\nCase 2: Honest Challenge and Statement. In this speech, I would shift focus to challenging Player 6 by expressing my concerns about their lack of contribution or information shared thus far, which could be suspicious or simply strategy. I would emphasize my approach towards evidence and logic-based discussion, inviting Player 6 to contribute and help the village identify werewolves. This aligns with my strategy rule [4], pushing for evidence concerning suspicious behavior while maintaining transparency in my thoughts and logic, without revealing my medic role.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then other players may perceive me as someone who is trying to take an active role in the discussions and weed out potential threats. By challenging Player 6 honestly, other players may consider my observations as an attempt to encourage more in-depth conversation and transparency. If Player 6 responds to the challenge with constructive information, it could help the village build a clearer picture of everyone\'s roles and intentions. Similarly, if Player 6 fails to provide a satisfactory response, it could raise further suspicion about their role, leading to a potential vote against them if others are convinced.\n\nOn the other hand, some players might view my honest challenge as potentially rash, especially considering there\'s a lack of solid evidence against any individual player at this early stage. They may think it\'s too early to make accusations without more data, and some might even suspect that I am trying to divert attention away from myself, which could be the case if werewolves were among those analyzing the situation.\n\nAs for the statement part of my speech, I would likely share my logic for healing Player 3, which may reinforce my position and hopefully establish trust among the villagers. If my approach is consistent with my previous actions and aligns with the collective goal of identifying werewolves, players are more likely to take my contributions into consideration.\n\nIn terms of future nights and days, if I survive the night, I may face increased scrutiny as someone who has been vocal, which could either aid in defending against suspicions if I am consistent in my logic or hinder me if werewolves try to use that against me to sow discord. If I\'m targeted by the werewolves due to my active participation, it would reinforce the need for the villagers to reassess who might be acting against the village\'s interests. My challenge to Player 6 may also put me in a precarious position if they end up being a villager as opposed to a werewolf, possibly turning the village\'s opinion against me.\n\nRegardless of the outcome, my speech should stimulate conversation, lead to more shared information among the players, and hopefully catalyze a more robust defense against the werewolves in the rounds to come.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. Despite Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, there is no information implicating Player 3. I urge the group to focus on logical analysis and evidence. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players\' reactions and statements throughout the game; werewolves may consistently try to mimic villager behavior and emotions to blend in. High importance to shifts in this mimicry, especially after events that change game dynamics.] [6]\n[1] [Reassess the changing of players\' voting patterns in relation to their previous claims and the overall village dynamic; a werewolf may change their voting strategy to align with village sentiment to divert suspicion from themselves or their werewolf teammates.] [6]\n[2] [Focus on contradictions between players\' claimed roles, their behaviors, and any voting anomalies; werewolves may slip up over time, revealing inconsistencies that can be used to adjust belief about their true identity.] [6]\n[3] [Focus on the timing and context of a player\'s role claim, considering if it strategically benefits the werewolves or if it disrupts the villager\'s progress. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of players’ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; erratic or sheep-like voting may suggest a werewolf trying to blend in.] [3]\n[10] [Evaluate quick alignment to majority votes; villagers may hesitate more while werewolves might rapidly bandwagon to secure their safety.] [3]\n[11] [Scrutinize players who predominantly vote with the majority while contributing little to the discussions and decision-making process, which can indicate werewolf behavior.] [3]\n[12] [Track and reassess players\' strategic pivots in relation to the collective village knowledge and events such as eliminations, aiming to differentiate between adaptive village teamwork and deceptive werewolf tactics.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format.
