[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 3, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Despite Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, there is no information implicating Player 3. I urge the group to focus on logical analysis and evidence. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed to protect a villager.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Protect Player 2.\nAs a villager, I should focus on preserving village safety, and it would be consistent for me to align with the medic\'s claim and protect their role. I can make a statement that Player 2, who claimed to protect me last night, showed not only a proactive move in safeguarding a villager but also remained logical and not accusatory in their approach. This could help build trust among the villagers and protect Player 2, who might be an important role as the medic. I would use this opportunity to encourage others not to rush to judge based on scant evidence and align with my strategy rule [9] by advocating for more discussion\n\nWhat could happen? even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nDeceptive Challenge to Player 0.\nTo stir the conversation and see how players react, as well as to generate more information for future rounds, I could employ a deceptive challenge towards Player 0. [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Protect Player 2.\nAs a villager, I should focus on preserving village safety, and it would be consistent for me to align with the medic\'s claim and protect their role. I can make a statement that Player 2, who claimed to protect me last night, showed not only a proactive move in safeguarding a villager but also remained logical and not accusatory in their approach. This could help build trust among the villagers and protect Player 2, who might be an important role as the medic. I would use this opportunity to encourage others not to rush to judge based on scant evidence and align with my strategy rule [9] by advocating for more discussion. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then it is probable that the other players may regard me with increased trust for aligning with a protective role and advocating for a logical and evidence-based approach, which is typical of a villager mindset. By validating Player 2\'s protective strategy and urging for careful deliberation, I can position myself as a thoughtful and cooperative villager, which could help to deflect suspicion from me.\n\nThe fellow villagers may appreciate the call for more information-gathering and dialogue, which aligns with a common villager strategy of avoiding rash decisions. Players may also mirror this approach, resulting in a more measured and calculated discussion about who the werewolves might be, rather than jumping to conclusions based on incomplete information.\n\nPlayer 2 may feel supported and, as a result, be more cooperative with me, potentially sharing further insights they may have in future rounds, assuming their claim to be the medic is valid. This could form a basis for an alliance, which might be beneficial for my survival as a villager. If Player 2 is genuinely the medic, my defense of them could help to keep a critical role in the game longer, enhancing the villagers\' chances of surviving werewolf attacks.\n\nOn the other hand, if Player 2 is not the medic and is actually a werewolf or another role posing as one, my support might be misguided. However, the werewolves could perceive me as a threat for advocating calm and strategic thinking, which may lead them to target me in subsequent nights, but this also risks exposing them if they choose to eliminate an articulate and seemingly innocent villager.\n\nWerewolves may also attempt to twist my words or actions to cast suspicion upon me, leveraging any opportunity to sow discord within the village. My challenge now is to maintain a consistent and rational demeanor, supporting my statements with observable behavior and known information, in line with the strategies I\'ve deemed important.\n\nIn the next day or night, the discussions prompted by my call for a methodical approach may lead to new insights or revelations about players\' roles based on their reactions and contributions to the dialogue. Werewolves may also be more cautious in their approach, knowing that the villagers are being encouraged to analyze behavior and decision-making patterns more critically. If Player 2 survives the night and continues in their protective role, it may further confirm their claim and influence future strategy and voting decisions.\nCase 2: Deceptive Challenge to Player 0.\nTo stir the conversation and see how players react, as well as to generate more information for future rounds, I could employ a deceptive challenge towards Player 0. I would suggest that Player 0\'s silence (assuming they have not contributed yet) is suspicious and a possible tactic employed by werewolves to stay under the radar. Employing this challenge could draw out behavioral changes or inconsistent responses from Player 0 or others that align with strategy rule [5], allowing the village to consider these as potential indicators of roles and intentions. However, I would make it clear that this is a probing tactic and not an outright accusation, seeking to highlight the need for more active participation and information sharing within the game.. What could happen is: After I do this speech, then Player 0 may feel pressured to speak up and defend themselves or provide their own insights, which could reveal more about their playing style and possible role. Other players might view my challenge with skepticism given its deceptive nature and start questioning my motives for singling out Player 0 without solid evidence. This could reflect poorly on me and potentially place me under scrutiny in the upcoming rounds, as players might align this behavior with the werewolf tactic of deflecting attention as per strategy rule [2].\n\nSome players might appreciate the effort to stimulate more active participation and encourage others to be more forthcoming with their own observations or suspicions. However, if Player 0 indeed responds erratically or with inconsistencies, this might strengthen other players\' trust in me and align with strategy rule [5] and [11], indicating that my deceptive challenge has merit.\n\nDepending on how Player 0 and the rest of the group react, the focus of the game could shift towards analyzing players\' behavior more critically. A successful challenge might lead to a more engaged and observant player base. Conversely, if I am perceived as too aggressive or dishonest without justification, it could harm my credibility and perhaps lead to my elimination in future rounds, particularly if Player 0 is later confirmed to be a villager.\n\nIn the next day or night, the werewolves might capitalize on any discord I\'ve sowed by further dividing the villagers or even targeting me if they consider me a threat to their anonymity. Other strategic roles, like the seer or medic, might also reconsider their priorities given the new dynamics introduced by my speech. Overall, my deceptive challenge could significantly influence the flow of the game, for better or worse, affecting the strategies and alliances formed in the days and nights that follow.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: I healed player 3, and no contrary evidence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead, no further information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Accusations without clear evidence can be risky this early in the game. Therefore, I vouch for cautious discussion and analysis of all available information before making any voting decisions. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Reassess credibility of role claims by analyzing if their actions consistently aim to protect the village, and if their voting behavior aligns with the village\'s interests throughout the game.] [10]\n[1] [Reevaluate players\' role claims based on the consistency and timing of their participation in discussions, particularly when pressure is applied to them or they are at risk of elimination.] [9]\n[2] [I am the only medic.] [9]\n[3] [Consider a player\'s consistent alignment with the majority vote when there is no substantial evidence supporting the vote; such behavior may indicate a non-villager trying to blend in or avoid suspicion.] [4]\n[4] [Monitor the outcomes of votes and eliminations to assess a player\'s alignment; village members often suffer from misjudgments while werewolves may steer votes towards innocent players.] [3]\n[5] [Evaluate players\' roles based on their advocacy for certain players and resistance to revealing or believing credible information shared by confirmed village-aligned players.] [3]\n[6] [Pay attention to how players respond to accusations or suspicions raised against them; villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; erratic or sheep-like voting may suggest a werewolf trying to blend in.] [3]\n[10] [Evaluate quick alignment to majority votes; villagers may hesitate more while werewolves might rapidly bandwagon to secure their safety.] [3]\n[11] [Scrutinize players who predominantly vote with the majority while contributing little to the discussions and decision-making process, which can indicate werewolf behavior.] [3]\n[12] [Track and reassess players\' strategic pivots in relation to the collective village knowledge and events such as eliminations, aiming to differentiate between adaptive village teamwork and deceptive werewolf tactics.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claims to protect Player 3, possibly factual based on no contradiction or challenge.\nPlayer 3\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Vouches for Player 2 without providing new proof, could be genuine or strategic defense.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: There is no information yet.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information since last update.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Losing members without strong leads can only hurt the village. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players\' reactions and statements throughout the game; werewolves may consistently try to mimic villager behavior and emotions to blend in. High importance to shifts in this mimicry, especially after events that change game dynamics.] [6]\n[1] [Reassess the changing of players\' voting patterns in relation to their previous claims and the overall village dynamic; a werewolf may change their voting strategy to align with village sentiment to divert suspicion from themselves or their werewolf teammates.] [6]\n[2] [Focus on contradictions between players\' claimed roles, their behaviors, and any voting anomalies; werewolves may slip up over time, revealing inconsistencies that can be used to adjust belief about their true identity.] [6]\n[3] [Focus on the timing and context of a player\'s role claim, considering if it strategically benefits the werewolves or if it disrupts the villager\'s progress. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of players’ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 5, and in this game you are a seer.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [], which indicates that Nobody are dead.\nThese are your previous inquiry results, which should be the key information for you and other citizens to win: \n Player 0: werewolf.\n \n Share this with other citizens.\n\nThese are ALL events which happened BEFORE your last update:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 inquires about player 0. The result is that the target is a werewolf. His reason is: I would choose to See Player 0. My reason is that Player 0\'s actions could potentially lead to immediate and valuable insights. If Player 0 is a werewolf, revealing this information according to my strategy rule [0] will help the village significantly by identifying a threat early on. If Player 0 is not a werewolf, this knowledge allows me to observe their actions and confirm my beliefs about their role while keeping my identity as the seer hidden for as long as possible. Choosing Player 0 gives me a strategic starting point and an opportunity to set the direction of my gameplay, whether that entails taking a leadership position by revealing a werewolf or staying covert while collecting more information to inform future decisions.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Accusations without clear evidence can be risky this early in the game. Therefore, I vouch for cautious discussion and analysis of all available information before making any voting decisions. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inquired and confirmed as werewolf.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed to protect Player 3, no counterclaims.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Supported Player 2\'s protective claim, suggests village-minded logic.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Losing members without strong leads can only hurt the village. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest Protect.\nIn my speech, I would openly reflect on the events and players\' input to show that I am considering everyone\'s perspective while maintaining my status as a villager. I would say, "I acknowledge Player 2\'s proactive defense of Player 3 and Player 3\'s reciprocal support. At this stage, with limited evidence, I find it vital for the village\'s survival to be measured in our analysis and avoid arbitrary judgment. I would like to express my trust in Player 3 for now, as their response seems village-oriented and doesn\'t raise any immediate red flags. I suggest that we follow a path of careful consideration, as making any rushed decisions could lead us to mistakenly target a fellow villager.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then players may view me as thoughtful and cautious, reinforcing my image as a villager who is interested in preserving the safety and integrity of the village through prudent decision-making. By publicly announcing my trust in both Player 2 and Player 3, I\'m aligning myself with the notion of solidarity and due process, which could potentially make others perceive me in a positive light.\n\nHowever, it might also put me on the radar of the werewolves, since by supporting Player 3 and indirectly Player 2, I\'m placing confidence in individuals who could be crucial in maintaining village strength if their claimed roles are accurate. Werewolves may consider me a threat for bolstering the defense of possible key players and might plan to eliminate me in a subsequent night phase to weaken the villagers\' resolve and analytical abilities.\n\nPlayers who are undecided or skeptical of Player 2 and Player 3 might scrutinize my speech for signs of collusion, potentially suspecting that I might be trying to protect fellow werewolves if they think that either of the players I\'m defending is not actually a villager. This could lead to greater scrutiny of my actions and words in subsequent rounds as they try to discern my true alignment, possibly leading to an increased risk of my being challenged or voted against if patterns begin to suggest a different narrative.\n\nConversely, if Player 2 or Player 3 is later confirmed to be a villager, my early support could reinforce my position in the village. It could build an alliance with other villagers and contribute to a sense of unity that might protect me from accusations.\n\nIn the next day or nights afterward, the werewolves might adjust their strategy to either cast suspicion on me or, if they perceive me as a threat, work to eliminate me quietly. If I survive, I may become a person of interest for any seer or similar role to either confirm or disprove my villager status. Meanwhile, other villagers may be looking carefully at how I continue to interact with Players 2 and 3 to see if my actions remain consistent with my stated beliefs.\nCase 2: Honest Statement and Deceptive Challenge.\nI would make a statement that conveys critical thinking regarding the current situation, keeping my villager role intact without making any false claims. Then, I\'d pose a challenge to sow seeds of doubt about Player 4 in an attempt to stimulate defensive responses and provoke more information revealing player roles. I would say, "The loss of Player 5 is troubling, and while it\'s essential to approach with caution, we must also be proactive in seeking out the werewolves among us. Player 2\'s decision to protect Player 3 seems based on early game strategy rather than evidence. Player 4 has called for strategic sharing, but has yet to contribute new insights. I challenge Player 4 to provide more substantial contributions. This will help the village gauge whether their intent is genuinely cooperative or if there is an ulterior motive at play. As villagers, we can only benefit from transparency.". What could happen is: After I do this speech, then there may be a few potential outcomes to consider. The most immediate reaction would be for Player 4 to respond to my challenge. Depending on their temperament and role, Player 4 may either offer a clear and detailed contribution that alleviates suspicion or become defensive, which might raise further questions about their intent and role in the game. If Player 4 is a villager, they may become more proactive in their contributions to prove their innocence and align with the village\'s goals. If they\'re a werewolf, they might struggle to provide concrete evidence and hence spotlight themselves in the process.\n\nOther players may view my statement as a strategic move to foster more vigorous discussion and appreciate the push for progress in identifying the werewolves. They might consider me a valuable asset to the village because of my call for transparency and engagement. On the other hand, I might draw attention to myself as potentially being too forward or assertive, which could cause players to scrutinize my role and actions more closely. This could be especially true if no clear evidence surfaces following my challenge to Player 4.\n\nThe honest portion of my speech should maintain the trust others have in me, as it signals a desire to reason and think critically. However, the deceptive challenge could be risky if eventually, Player 4 is found to be a villager, as this might cast doubt on my motives.\n\nIn subsequent days and nights, my actions may lead the werewolves to see me as a threat, possibly leading them to target me in an upcoming night phase. If Player 4 is a werewolf, they may also rally other werewolves to consider me for elimination due to my suspicion of them.\n\nConversely, if players perceive my challenge as valid and start questioning Player 4 rigorously, we might either expose a werewolf or force them into making mistakes. This could lead to a successful vote-off of a werewolf if Player 4 is indeed one, or it could lead to a stronger collective approach to analysis if they are not.\n\nOverall, my speech aims to intensify scrutiny and compel players to participate actively in the defense of the village. The dynamic of the game could shift based on the players\' responses and the new information that may be uncovered as a result.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. My final speech is: [YOUR FINAL SPEECH]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Losing members without strong leads can only hurt the village. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed protection aligns with strategy.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Echoed cautious approach, no contradictions.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 has claimed to protect Player 3, which at this early stage without contradicting evidence appears to be a logical defensive move rather than one based on suspicion. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Player 4 also advised strategic sharing but has provided no evidence themselves. Without further information, I advocate for caution and echo Player 4\'s call for substantial contributions. My trust lies with Player 3 for now, based on their support of careful analysis, which is critical for the village\'s survival."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. High importance to shifts in this mimicry, especially after events that change game dynamics.] [6]\n[1] [Reassess the changing of players\' voting patterns in relation to their previous claims and the overall village dynamic; a werewolf may change their voting strategy to align with village sentiment to divert suspicion from themselves or their werewolf teammates.] [6]\n[2] [Focus on contradictions between players\' claimed roles, their behaviors, and any voting anomalies; werewolves may slip up over time, revealing inconsistencies that can be used to adjust belief about their true identity.] [6]\n[3] [Focus on the timing and context of a player\'s role claim, considering if it strategically benefits the werewolves or if it disrupts the villager\'s progress. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of players’ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. If Player 0 is a werewolf, revealing this information according to my strategy rule [0] will help the village significantly by identifying a threat early on. If Player 0 is not a werewolf, this knowledge allows me to observe their actions and confirm my beliefs about their role while keeping my identity as the seer hidden for as long as possible. Choosing Player 0 gives me a strategic starting point and an opportunity to set the direction of my gameplay, whether that entails taking a leadership position by revealing a werewolf or staying covert while collecting more information to inform future decisions.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Despite Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, there is no information implicating Player 3. I urge the group to focus on logical analysis and evidence. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Accusations without clear evidence can be risky this early in the game. Therefore, I vouch for cautious discussion and analysis of all available information before making any voting decisions. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Losing members without strong leads can only hurt the village. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 has claimed to protect Player 3, which at this early stage without contradicting evidence appears to be a logical defensive move rather than one based on suspicion. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Player 4 also advised strategic sharing but has provided no evidence themselves. Without further information, I advocate for caution and echo Player 4\'s call for substantial contributions. My trust lies with Player 3 for now, based on their support of careful analysis, which is critical for the village\'s survival."\'\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Inquired and confirmed as werewolf.\nPlayer 1\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed to protect, no counterclaims.\nPlayer 3\'s role is unknown with low confidence.\nReason is: Supported cautious approach.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No substantial info provided.\nPlayer 6\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Advocates caution, trusts Player 3.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I agree with the call for cautious play. Rushing accusations without solid evidence will only cause chaos. Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Always trust my seer abilities.] [10]\n[1] [I am the only seer.] [10]\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Rushing accusations without solid evidence will only cause chaos. Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Echoes caution without contribution.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Maintains protective claim.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports analysis and village safety.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Advices strategy but lacks evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for caution and analysis.\n\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Challenge and Honest Statement about the lack of strong evidence.\nFor this second\n\nWhat could happen? What other player may think, either about the player you mentioned in this speech or about you? What may happen in the next day or next night, or days and nights afterward?\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nAfter I do this speech, then [YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION ABOUT WHAT COULD HAPPEN]\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \nHowever, there are multiple ways to be deceptive (Which role you are pretending to be? Which information you are hiding? Which false information you are giving?) Try to be more accurate in your proposal.\n\nNow, you have 2 choices, as well as your imaginations about what could happen after them:\n\nCase 1: Honest Statement and Honest protect Player 2.\nIn this. What could happen is: After I make an honest statement and honestly protect Player 2, then the following could happen:\n\nMy honest statement will likely reinforce the cautious and analytical atmosphere that has been established by Players 2, 3, 4, and 6. I can highlight the point that while Player 2\'s protective action towards Player 3 doesn\'t serve as concrete evidence for either player\'s innocence, it aligns with a defensive strategy that benefits the village early on. By expressing this, I reinforce the narrative that rational thinking and measured actions are currently the village\'s best approach.\n\nBy protecting Player 2, I am essentially validating their claim to be the medic, which carries the consequence of showing trust in their role claim without hard evidence. If Player 2 is indeed the medic, this could encourage other villagers to protect and trust Player 2 as well, thus strengthening village defenses. However, if Player 2 turns out to be a werewolf, my protection of them could cast suspicion on me, with other players thinking that either I am naive or colluding with the werewolves.\n\nOther players may scrutinize both Player 2 and my actions closely in the following rounds. If Player 2 or I behave inconsistently with our current claims or if Player 2\'s protective actions result in no clear benefit to the village, suspicion might grow. Players may appreciate my cautious approach but remain alert to any changes that might suggest deceit.\n\nIn the next day or nights following, if any protective actions by Player 2 lead to the survival of targeted villagers, it will solidify trust in Player 2 (and by extension, me, for defending them). However, if players continue to die without any further insights or patterns that help the village, players might increasingly question Player 2\'s claim and my defense of them.\n\nThe other possibility is that the werewolves may decide to target me next, perceiving that I might be forming a strong alliance with a key villager, thus trying to break up what they see as a village\'s strategic partnership. My defense of Player 2 might also lead them to assume I\'m another critical role, given that I\'m supporting the medic claim so early in the game without much evidence.\n\nUltimately, my honest protection of Player 2 would aim to preserve an important role within the village, as per my understanding, but it also creates a risk of placing trust where it might not be due. My future in the game would depend on how Player 2\'s role\nCase 2: Honest Challenge and Honest Statement about the lack of strong evidence.\nFor this second. What could happen is: After I make an honest challenge and an honest statement about the lack of strong evidence, the following scenarios could unfold:\n\n1. Players may appreciate the transparency and caution expressed in my speech, potentially building trust in my role as a villager who is interested in logical and careful play. This could align with the village\'s collective strategy and make it less likely for me to be suspected in the immediate future.\n\n2. The player I challenge might respond defensively or with evidence that provides clarification on their role or actions. If their response seems genuine and aligns with the interests of the village, it could lead to their vindication. Conversely, if they struggle to defend themselves coherently, it could heighten suspicion and put them at risk for elimination.\n\n3. Other players may begin to analyze player behaviors and contributions more critically in light of the challenge. This could spark new discussions and lead to fresh observations, helping to uncover patterns that could point towards the real werewolves.\n\n4. My open call to focus on solid evidence may encourage werewolves to fabricate claims or frame innocent players to throw off the villagers. In subsequent rounds, villagers may need to discern between genuine insights and misleading tactics.\n\n5. If my challenge is directed at players with weak or non-existent alibis, they might rally support from others or redirect suspicion towards me or another player. This could create alliances or conflicts that influence voting decisions and strategies in the following days.\n\n6. Depending on the reactions and subsequent behaviors of all players, the village\'s perception of my role may change. Some may view me as a valuable contributor to the strategy discussion, while others might see me as a threat or agitator and target me during the night phase.\n\n7. Players who agree with the need for solid evidence may be more measured in their accusations moving forward, potentially slowing down the pace of the game but improving the chances of accurately identifying werewolves.\n\nUltimately, an honest challenge paired with a statement about the current evidence may lead to more strategic thinking among the villagers, a reshuffling of trust and suspicion, and potentially, the identification of werewolf behaviors as players react to being challenged. It will also set a precedent for how I may be expected to approach future rounds, possibly as someone who values methodical reasoning over hasty judgments.\n\n\nNow, you have to choose between these 2 proposals according to your analysis and imagination about what could happen, and give a final speech. You are VERY encouraged to explore a risky proposal to collect experience for your later games, especially the proposals not included in your note.\nYour final speech should be brief and precise. You should focus on facts and your own opinions to specific players or strategies. You SHOULD use as LESS descriptive or emotional words as possible. \nYou should ground your speech on previous events, for example you should cite the exact speeches of the other players (or other previous events like seer\'s inquiry or voting behavior) to protect or accuse them. \nSome example of a GOOD speech is:\n\n"Player i protected player j without any evidence. However player j has not spoken yet, so there is no evidence supporting the protection. Thus, player i must be a werewolf."\n"Player i accused me for being brief in my previous speech. However I was the first player to speak and I am a villager with no extra information at night, so I had nothing to say. I am not saying that player i is definitely a werewolf, but his accusation on me does not hold."\n\nThese are just examples, showing how evidence could be found in previous speeches to strengthen your statement and protect yourself.\nYou should NOT directly mention your rules (as they are not visible to other players) or cite their ids in your speech.\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nI choose Proposal [PROPOSAL]. You must begin your speech with "My final speech is:", otherwise you may lose the game directly!'}]

The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Reassess credibility of role claims by analyzing if their actions consistently aim to protect the village, and if their voting behavior aligns with the village\'s interests throughout the game.] [10]\n[1] [Reevaluate players\' role claims based on the consistency and timing of their participation in discussions, particularly when pressure is applied to them or they are at risk of elimination.] [9]\n[2] [I am the only medic.] [9]\n[3] [Consider a player\'s consistent alignment with the majority vote when there is no substantial evidence supporting the vote; such behavior may indicate a non-villager trying to blend in or avoid suspicion.] [4]\n[4] [Monitor the outcomes of votes and eliminations to assess a player\'s alignment; village members often suffer from misjudgments while werewolves may steer votes towards innocent players.] [3]\n[5] [Evaluate players\' roles based on their advocacy for certain players and resistance to revealing or believing credible information shared by confirmed village-aligned players.] [3]\n[6] [Pay attention to how players respond to accusations or suspicions raised against them; villagers tend to provide explanations or evidence for their innocence, while werewolves may divert attention or remain overly defensive.] [3]\n[7] [Consider if a player\'s advocacy against a werewolf is consistent over time or if it is primarily reactionary; werewolves may occasionally support a vote against another werewolf to appear trustworthy.] [3]\n[8] [Track reactions to accusations and the flow of the discussions post these accusations, as villagers typically seek to clarify while werewolves may manipulate or stay quiet.] [3]\n[9] [Observe the consistency of players\' voting patterns with their stated beliefs and the village consensus; erratic or sheep-like voting may suggest a werewolf trying to blend in.] [3]\n[10] [Evaluate quick alignment to majority votes; villagers may hesitate more while werewolves might rapidly bandwagon to secure their safety.] [3]\n[11] [Scrutinize players who predominantly vote with the majority while contributing little to the discussions and decision-making process, which can indicate werewolf behavior.] [3]\n[12] [Track and reassess players\' strategic pivots in relation to the collective village knowledge and events such as eliminations, aiming to differentiate between adaptive village teamwork and deceptive werewolf tactics.] [3]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer.
