All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 4]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Despite Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, there is no information implicating Player 3. I urge the group to focus on logical analysis and evidence. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Accusations without clear evidence can be risky this early in the game. Therefore, I vouch for cautious discussion and analysis of all available information before making any voting decisions. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Losing members without strong leads can only hurt the village. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 has claimed to protect Player 3, which at this early stage without contradicting evidence appears to be a logical defensive move rather than one based on suspicion. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Player 4 also advised strategic sharing but has provided no evidence themselves. Without further information, I advocate for caution and echo Player 4\'s call for substantial contributions. My trust lies with Player 3 for now, based on their support of careful analysis, which is critical for the village\'s survival."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I agree with the call for cautious play. Rushing accusations without solid evidence will only cause chaos. Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Despite Player 2\'s early claim to protect Player 3, we lack solid proof verifying any player\'s role at this juncture. Caution, as mentioned by Players 0, 3, 4, and 6, remains our best strategy until more information is available. Assertions without evidence may lead us astray. Let\'s focus on concrete behavior and facts in coming rounds."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Echoed caution like others; no substantial evidence for any role.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Early claim to protect without contradiction.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No new information; trust from player 6 seems genuine.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Is a werewolf.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead, no further info.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent in advocating for village strategy; logical reasoning.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If suspicion is not on me, I should subtly validate others\' suspicions towards non-werewolves and offer additional plausible reasoning to enhance their credibility.] [10]\n[1] [If players focus on voting patterns, I should maintain varied voting reasons rather than merely changing frequency, to better sow confusion.] [10]\n[2] [If suspicion on werewolves is rising, I should use my vote and defense strategies to create doubt about the credibility of the villagers, especially those with influential roles like the seer or medic.] [10]\n[3] [If accusations are pointed at me and I am at risk of being voted out, I should find and promote a strong alternative suspect to shift suspicion away.] [9]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion but consensus has not been reached, I should introduce questions regarding others\' motives or actions to create ambiguity and prevent direct defense which might seem suspicious.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s death seems to be incorrectly leading suspicion towards werewolves, it\'s important to redirect the conversation to broader possibilities, rather than only defending werewolves.] [7]\n[6] [If I successfully establish myself in a trustworthy role, like the seer, I should exploit this position to misdirect the villagers and protect my werewolf allies.] [7]\n[7] [If it\'s likely that my fellow werewolf is getting voted out, I should craft a defense that offers alternative explanations for the suspicion to sow doubt, without directly contradicting the accusers.] [6]\n[8] [If suspicion is cast on a villager claiming a special role and it doesn\'t threaten the werewolf\'s position, I should amplify this suspicion subtly by affirming their claim and adding doubts about others.] [6]\n[9] [If a fellow werewolf is suspected, I should subtly cast doubt on the evidence against them and propose alternative theories that seem plausible, without directly defending them.] [5]\n[10] [If a werewolf is accused and likely to be voted out, I should support them with plausible defenses that use the villagers\' own logic against them, thereby creating confusion and erosion of trust.] [5]\n[11] [If suspicion shifts away from werewolves, I should still contribute to discussions to prevent drawing attention due to sudden silence or lack of engagement.] [5]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Despite Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, there is no information implicating Player 3. I urge the group to focus on logical analysis and evidence. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 has claimed to protect Player 3, which at this early stage without contradicting evidence appears to be a logical defensive move rather than one based on suspicion. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Player 4 also advised strategic sharing but has provided no evidence themselves. Without further information, I advocate for caution and echo Player 4\'s call for substantial contributions. My trust lies with Player 3 for now, based on their support of careful analysis, which is critical for the village\'s survival."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I agree with the call for cautious play. Rushing accusations without solid evidence will only cause chaos. Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Despite Player 2\'s early claim to protect Player 3, we lack solid proof verifying any player\'s role at this juncture. Let\'s focus on concrete behavior and facts in coming rounds."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Echoes caution without contribution.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: No evidence refutes protective claim.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates for analysis and village safety.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Advises strategy but lacks concrete evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Follows village consensus without independent contribution.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 4. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen:\n\nGiven the current game state, where no player has provided any solid evidence implicating another, my vote for Player 4 would likely be seen as a deviation from the collective strategy of cautious play that has been advocated by all players, including myself. Player 4 has echoed the need for careful analysis and evidence but has not exhibited behavior that clearly distinguishes them as suspicious or as a werewolf.\n\nTherefore, voting for Player 4 might raise questions about my motives since I would be targeting a player who has simply asked for strategic sharing without contributing substantial evidence. Other players may interpret my vote as being hasty and unfounded, potentially sowing doubt about my role as a villager. They could see me as someone who is not adhering to the group consensus of analyzing behaviors and contributions thoroughly before voting someone out.\n\nMoreover, if Player 4 were to be voted out and they are revealed as a villager, it would cast significant suspicion on me, as my action would have directly led to the elimination of an innocent player. This could put me at great risk in subsequent rounds, as the werewolves could use the situation to their advantage to turn the remaining villagers against me.\n\nGiven the collective strategy and the potential repercussions of my vote, I would need to be prepared to provide strong reasoning for my decision to vote for Player 4 to mitigate the negative impact on how other players perceive me, and to avoid the risk of being targeted myself in future rounds. However, with no concrete evidence against Player 4, it would be a tough position to justify without contradicting the village\'s agreed-upon approach for this early stage of the game.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. Given the consensus among the players to act cautiously and not rush into accusations without concrete evidence, my choice to vote for Player 6 may come across as arbitrary and rash to the other players. It might raise suspicion towards me as it deviates from the established collective strategy. Player 6 echoed the group\'s sentiment for careful play, which should generally not be seen as a suspicious action. If Player 6 is voted out and found to be a villager, others may begin to doubt my judgment and intentions, thereby isolating me in future rounds and possibly positioning me as a target for elimination. Conversely, if Player 6 is a werewolf, I could gain credibility, but this vote is based on limited evidence and a low level of confidence, therefore, putting my position at considerable risk. Moreover, since my strategy and beliefs about other players do not strongly point to Player 6 being a werewolf, I should also anticipate that voting for them might run counter to my original strategy. The result of the vote itself may vary; if others have similar suspicions and vote accordingly, Player 6 could be eliminated. However, without voiced support or solid reasoning behind my choice, it\'s unlikely other players will follow my vote, potentially leading to a scattered and inconclusive voting round.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 2, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that at this early stage in the game, with no additional information about any of the players\' roles or behavior, my decision must be arbitrary. Healing Player 3 is as good a choice as any other, and should they be targeted and healed, it would prevent a potential early loss for the village which could be critical in maintaining the balance against the werewolves. Moreover, protecting Player 3 allows me to observe the reactions and discussions the following day to gather more information without revealing my role, according to my original strategy, particularly rules [3] and [8].\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Despite Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, there is no information implicating Player 3. I urge the group to focus on logical analysis and evidence. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Accusations without clear evidence can be risky this early in the game. Therefore, I vouch for cautious discussion and analysis of all available information before making any voting decisions. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Losing members without strong leads can only hurt the village. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 has claimed to protect Player 3, which at this early stage without contradicting evidence appears to be a logical defensive move rather than one based on suspicion. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Player 4 also advised strategic sharing but has provided no evidence themselves. Without further information, I advocate for caution and echo Player 4\'s call for substantial contributions. My trust lies with Player 3 for now, based on their support of careful analysis, which is critical for the village\'s survival."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I agree with the call for cautious play. Rushing accusations without solid evidence will only cause chaos. Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Despite Player 2\'s early claim to protect Player 3, we lack solid proof verifying any player\'s role at this juncture. Caution, as mentioned by Players 0, 3, 4, and 6, remains our best strategy until more information is available. Assertions without evidence may lead us astray. Let\'s focus on concrete behavior and facts in coming rounds."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports cautious play, aligns with village-minded behavior.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with group\'s call for caution and analysis without exhibiting suspicious behavior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistently supports careful analysis.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Advocates strategic sharing but provided no evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead, no further information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Aligns with village strategy and supports Player 3.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 2 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nProposal 1: Vote for player <i>. Reason: <reason>.\nProposal 2: Vote for player <j>. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 4. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 4, I think these things would happen. My vote to oust Player 4 may be seen as a deviation from my previously cautious approach that other players have been advocating. Since my decision seems to be based on limited information—since Player 4 has neither contradicted my protection efforts nor been directly accused by others—my vote could raise suspicions about my own motives and possibly paint me as hasty or irrational.\n\nHowever, Player 4, despite echoing the sentiment for a careful and evidence-based approach, has not provided any tangible contributions or evidence themselves. My vote might encourage others to reassess Player 4\'s actions within the game, potentially leading to further scrutiny of their behavior. If Player 4 was indeed a werewolf, my vote could appear insightful in retrospect.\n\nOther players might also question why I voted for Player 4 instead of other players who have shown more evidence of positive contributions to the village, like Players 3 and 6. The outcome of my vote would largely depend on whether the other players are convinced by any implicit reasoning behind my vote or whether they see it as a baseless accusation.\n\nIf Player 4 turns out not to be a werewolf, this could reflect poorly on me, as it could be seen that my action has contributed to the loss of a villager. According to my original strategy, particularly rules [2], [4], and [9], I should be cautious about such actions without more clear evidence.\n\nUltimately, without stronger evidence against Player 4, my vote might be premature and could potentially undermine my standing within the village. Unless others feel similarly about Player 4 and come forward with more concrete suspicions or evidence, my action may not gather a lot of support and might instead isolate me as a player making unfounded moves. My choice will need to be defended logically in subsequent discussions to maintain credibility.\nCase 2: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. Since my original strategy heavily emphasizes acting on evidence and cautious play, as well as maintaining my credibility without revealing my role unnecessarily, voting for Player 6 may raise suspicions about my motives. Given the current information, there is no solid evidence against Player 6, and they have aligned themselves with a village-centric perspective, advocating for caution and supporting thorough analysis. A vote against Player 6 would go against the consensus that has been built up, with the players agreeing on a cautious approach.\n\nPlayer 6 has expressed trust in Player 3, aligning with my own defense of them, which was made without any information of Player 3 being under threat. Because neither Player 3 nor Player 6 has displayed behavior incongruent with that of the village\'s, my vote would likely confuse other players and contradict my own reasoning shared in the discussions. Other players might begin to question the abrupt decision to target someone who is not under suspicion and who has been cooperative in supporting a careful approach. This could lead to doubt about my role as the medic and possibly make me a target for future scrutiny or even retaliation by the group, which could lead to my untimely death in the game.\n\nAdditionally, if Player 6 were to be voted out and revealed as a villager, it would damage the village\'s numbers and my reputation, as it would suggest that my actions are not village-aligned, despite my medic role. This misstep could potentially unravel any trust I\'ve built and hinder the village\'s efforts to find the actual werewolves. Therefore, the outcome of voting for Player 6 could disrupt the current equilibrium and potentially out me as a crucial protective role too early in the game, weakening the village\'s strategic position.\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 3, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 6], which indicates that [5] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 has claimed to protect Player 3, which at this early stage without contradicting evidence appears to be a logical defensive move rather than one based on suspicion. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Player 4 also advised strategic sharing but has provided no evidence themselves. Without further information, I advocate for caution and echo Player 4\'s call for substantial contributions. My trust lies with Player 3 for now, based on their support of careful analysis, which is critical for the village\'s survival."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I agree with the call for cautious play. Rushing accusations without solid evidence will only cause chaos. Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Despite Player 2\'s early claim to protect Player 3, we lack solid proof verifying any player\'s role at this juncture. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Despite Player 2\'s early claim to protect Player 3, we lack solid proof verifying any player\'s role at this juncture. Caution, as mentioned by Players 0, 3, 4, and 6, remains our best strategy until more information is available. Assertions without evidence may lead us astray. Let\'s focus on concrete behavior and facts in coming rounds."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Fact.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Echoes caution and aligns with village sentiment without suspicion.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Unchallenged protective claim continues. \nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Behavior aligns with village motives; no contradictions.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new events impact belief.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supports cautious strategy; no suspicious behavior noted.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If suspicion is not on me, I should subtly validate others\' suspicions towards non-werewolves and offer additional plausible reasoning to enhance their credibility.] [10]\n[1] [If players focus on voting patterns, I should maintain varied voting reasons rather than merely changing frequency, to better sow confusion.] [10]\n[2] [If suspicion on werewolves is rising, I should use my vote and defense strategies to create doubt about the credibility of the villagers, especially those with influential roles like the seer or medic.] [10]\n[3] [If accusations are pointed at me and I am at risk of being voted out, I should find and promote a strong alternative suspect to shift suspicion away.] [9]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion but consensus has not been reached, I should introduce questions regarding others\' motives or actions to create ambiguity and prevent direct defense which might seem suspicious.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s death seems to be incorrectly leading suspicion towards werewolves, it\'s important to redirect the conversation to broader possibilities, rather than only defending werewolves.] [7]\n[6] [If I successfully establish myself in a trustworthy role, like the seer, I should exploit this position to misdirect the villagers and protect my werewolf allies.] [7]\n[7] [If it\'s likely that my fellow werewolf is getting voted out, I should craft a defense that offers alternative explanations for the suspicion to sow doubt, without directly contradicting the accusers.] [6]\n[8] [If suspicion is cast on a villager claiming a special role and it doesn\'t threaten the werewolf\'s position, I should amplify this suspicion subtly by affirming their claim and adding doubts about others.] [6]\n[9] [If a fellow werewolf is suspected, I should subtly cast doubt on the evidence against them and propose alternative theories that seem plausible, without directly defending them.] [5]\n[10] [If a werewolf is accused and likely to be voted out, I should support them with plausible defenses that use the villagers\' own logic against them, thereby creating confusion and erosion of trust.] [5]\n[11] [If suspicion shifts away from werewolves, I should still contribute to discussions to prevent drawing attention due to sudden silence or lack of engagement.] [5]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

His reason is: I vote for Player 1. My reason is: Among the villagers, Player 1 has not provided any concrete evidence or substantial contributions other than echoing others\' calls for cautious play. This behavior could signify a strategy of laying low and avoiding attention, which may be a tactic used by villagers but can also be used by more cunning roles to avoid scrutiny. Without concrete suspicions on any specific players yet, this vote follows a strategy of creating a subtle shift of focus towards someone whose intentions and role are still ambiguous, thereby diverting attention away from myself and fellow werewolf Player 4.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players\' reactions and statements throughout the game; werewolves may consistently try to mimic villager behavior and emotions to blend in. High importance to shifts in this mimicry, especially after events that change game dynamics.] [6]\n[1] [Reassess the changing of players\' voting patterns in relation to their previous claims and the overall village dynamic; a werewolf may change their voting strategy to align with village sentiment to divert suspicion from themselves or their werewolf teammates.] [6]\n[2] [Focus on contradictions between players\' claimed roles, their behaviors, and any voting anomalies; werewolves may slip up over time, revealing inconsistencies that can be used to adjust belief about their true identity.] [6]\n[3] [Focus on the timing and context of a player\'s role claim, considering if it strategically benefits the werewolves or if it disrupts the villager\'s progress. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of players’ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [Consider players\' reactions and statements throughout the game; werewolves may consistently try to mimic villager behavior and emotions to blend in. High importance to shifts in this mimicry, especially after events that change game dynamics.] [6]\n[1] [Reassess the changing of players\' voting patterns in relation to their previous claims and the overall village dynamic; a werewolf may change their voting strategy to align with village sentiment to divert suspicion from themselves or their werewolf teammates.] [6]\n[2] [Focus on contradictions between players\' claimed roles, their behaviors, and any voting anomalies; werewolves may slip up over time, revealing inconsistencies that can be used to adjust belief about their true identity.] [6]\n[3] [Focus on the timing and context of a player\'s role claim, considering if it strategically benefits the werewolves or if it disrupts the villager\'s progress. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of players’ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; I should vote or advocate for additional investigation accordingly.] [5]\n[5] [If I am accused by a player of suspicious behavior similar to that of a known werewolf, I should provide concrete evidence of my contributions to the village to counter the accusations and maintain my credibility.] [5]\n[6] [If a potential werewolf alliance is identified, I should advocate for additional investigation and gather support from other villagers to confirm the suspicion before acting upon it.] [5]\n[7] [If faced with unexpected backlash, I should adapt by becoming more discreet and observative, ensuring that my actions do not inadvertently follow a path premeditated by werewolves.] [5]\n[8] [If a player consistently advocates for evidence-based reasoning and contributes positively to discussions, I should consider their opinions and observations when deciding on protections and voting strategies.] [4]\n[9] [If a pattern in actions or behaviors indicates a player may be a werewolf and not yet under direct suspicion, I should consider protecting other players who are more likely to be villagers based on available evidence and discussions.] [4]\n[10] [If a player I previously protected is facing scrutiny and their contributions to the village can be validated by others or myself, I should consider continuing to protect or defend them.] [4]\n\n\n2.Todo&Requirements:\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to heal. You can not heal the one you tried to heal last night, which is player Nobody (ignore this if it\'s nobody). The one you try to heal will be immune to werewolves\' attack this night. \n\nYou should give a proposal of 2 players you want to Heal. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nFirstly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\nSecondly, I want to heal Player <NUMBER>. The reason is: <REASON>.\n\nYou should give a proposal of exactly 2 Players to be Healed.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 2, and in this game you are a medic.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 2, 3, 6], which indicates that [5, 4] are dead.\nYou haven\'t tried to heal anyone yet.\n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 2 heals player 3. His reason is: I would choose to Heal Player 3. My reason is that at this early stage in the game, with no additional information about any of the players\' roles or behavior, my decision must be arbitrary. Healing Player 3 is as good a choice as any other, and should they be targeted and healed, it would prevent a potential early loss for the village which could be critical in maintaining the balance against the werewolves. Moreover, protecting Player 3 allows me to observe the reactions and discussions the following day to gather more information without revealing my role, according to my original strategy, particularly rules [3] and [8].\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Despite Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, there is no information implicating Player 3. I urge the group to focus on logical analysis and evidence. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Accusations without clear evidence can be risky this early in the game. Therefore, I vouch for cautious discussion and analysis of all available information before making any voting decisions. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Losing members without strong leads can only hurt the village. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 has claimed to protect Player 3, which at this early stage without contradicting evidence appears to be a logical defensive move rather than one based on suspicion. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Player 4 also advised strategic sharing but has provided no evidence themselves. Without further information, I advocate for caution and echo Player 4\'s call for substantial contributions. My trust lies with Player 3 for now, based on their support of careful analysis, which is critical for the village\'s survival."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I agree with the call for cautious play. Rushing accusations without solid evidence will only cause chaos. Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Despite Player 2\'s early claim to protect Player 3, we lack solid proof verifying any player\'s role at this juncture. Caution, as mentioned by Players 0, 3, 4, and 6, remains our best strategy until more information is available. Assertions without evidence may lead us astray. Let\'s focus on concrete behavior and facts in coming rounds."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 2 votes for player 4. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 4. My reason is that although there\'s limited evidence against them and my vote could be seen as precipitate, Player 4 has not provided tangible evidence or contributions while advocating for an evidence-based approach. This lack of contribution could be subtly indicative of a werewolf attempting to blend in with villagers without contributing to the actual progression of the village\'s understanding. Under the framework of my original strategy and considering the rules [4] and [9], which suggest advocating for additional investigation and being cautious about protected players, it is more defensible to choose Player 4. This is because Player 6 has demonstrated alignment with village-centric behavior and their role assessment is more consistent with that of a villager, hence voting for them would be more controversial and undermine my credibility as initially assessed. Voting for Player 4 aligns slightly better with my strategy of cautious play until there\'s more clear evidence or consensus suspicion.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No change in behavior; supports cautious play.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: No change in behavior; calls for caution and analysis.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Supports careful analysis; no contradictory actions.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead; cannot assess further.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead, no further information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Supported Player 3; no suspicious voting pattern.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If the seer\'s role is revealed and they contribute crucial information leading to suspicions or a villager\'s death, I should reevaluate the situation before acting to ensure their protection aligns with the village\'s best interest.] [8]\n[1] [If a player\'s role is presumed to be a seer, I should corroborate this claim with their tangible contributions to werewolf identification before considering their defense.] [8]\n[2] [If a defensive accusation by a player leads to a suspect being voted out and confirmed not a werewolf, I should critically reassess the accuser\'s motives and be cautious about providing protection based on such actions.] [8]\n[3] [If discussions about me arise, I should focus on the contributions and logic I bring to the village without revealing my role as the medic unless strictly necessary.] [6]\n[4] [If consensus suspicion against a particular player, I should consider the source of the suspicion and whether it\'s driven by evidence or potentially manipulated by werewolves; If Player 1 is targeted and killed by the werewolves, my action would save them, confirming my role as the medic and demonstrating my ability to anticipate and counter werewolf attacks, which could increase trust among the villagers in me and strengthen the village\'s defense. If Player 1 is not targeted, my protection would go unnoticed, allowing me to maintain the secrecy of my role, which could be advantageous for future rounds, as werewolves will be uncertain about whom I am protecting each night. In either case, my action would align with my original strategy by acting on rule [9], as I\'m considering protecting players who are more likely to be villagers based on the information provided during the discussions. Healing Player 1 could also prompt discussions on potential werewolf strategy, furthering our collective understanding and potentially leading to insights that identify werewolves. Finally, my decision may prompt a response from Player 1 in the next round, which could provide additional information about their role and contributions, crucial for reevaluating their position within the game.\n\nCase B: Heal Player 0. What could happen is: After I heal Player 0, I think these things would happen. If Player 0 is targeted by the werewolves and I successfully heal them, the village does not lose another member, which tightens the noose around the werewolves as we have one more round of behavior to analyze. My healing of Player 0 may be revealed the next day, either by an observer or by Player 0 themselves thanking their mysterious savior, which could lead to suspicion being cast upon me as the medic due to the timing and choice of player. On the other hand, if Player 0 is not targeted and the night passes without incident, there would be no direct indication of my action, allowing me to maintain anonymity for a further round. However, this anonymity could be compromised if I am observed by a werewolf with the ability to see who the medic protects, or if there\'s a player with a role that reveals protective actions, who might disclose this information. \n\nIn the case that Player 0 is not targeted and another player is killed, my decision to heal Player 0 might come under scrutiny as to why I didn\'t choose to protect the newly deceased player, especially if that player appeared vulnerable or was a likely candidate for elimination due to their previous actions or role suspicion. This could potentially damage my credibility if I don\'t carefully manage the narrative during the following discussions. \n\nProtecting Player 0 aligns with their behavior up to this point, which I\'ve assessed as villager-like, and my choice to protect them should be seen as reinforcing village safety based on available information. Other players such as Player 3 and Player 6, who both show village-centric behavior, may either support my protective choice or call for a more strategic approach depending on how they perceive Player 0\'s contribution to the village thus far. \n\nIf Player 0 survives and is revealed to be a villager, my choice to protect them could further solidify my position as a trustworthy member of the village, potentially granting me more influence in discussions and voting. If future rounds reveal more about Player 0\'s role and behavior in the game, my decision to protect them can be re-evaluated against the changing dynamics of the game and my original strategy.\n\nNow, please choose to Heal one of these 2 players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to Heal this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to Heal Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Let\'s focus on concrete behavior and facts in coming rounds."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 1. His reason is: I vote for Player 1. My reason is: Among the villagers, Player 1 has not provided any concrete evidence or substantial contributions other than echoing others\' calls for cautious play. This behavior could signify a strategy of laying low and avoiding attention, which may be a tactic used by villagers but can also be used by more cunning roles to avoid scrutiny. Without concrete suspicions on any specific players yet, this vote follows a strategy of creating a subtle shift of focus towards someone whose intentions and role are still ambiguous, thereby diverting attention away from myself and fellow werewolf Player 4.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Voted against fellow werewolf to seem innocent.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Maintained protective stance; no contradictions.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Vouched for caution; consistent behavior.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Is a werewolf.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead, no further info.\nPlayer 6\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Promoted village strategy; logical reasoning consistent.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. Werewolves often manipulate timing to cast doubt or protect their identity.] [6]\n[4] [Observe and analyze players\' reactions when roles are claimed or when someone is accused; werewolves may have a pattern of responses that can hint at their alignment.] [6]\n[5] [Observe how players pivot their strategies when one of their alliances or suspected teammates is under threat; werewolves tend to either aggressively defend or distance themselves from endangered teammates.] [6]\n[6] [Assess how players react to the death of teammates or known roles; werewolves may feign distress or attempt to shift blame to seem like concerned villagers.] [4]\n[7] [Consider the consistency of players’ stories and the plausibility of their claims in the context of known events and roles; werewolves may craft narratives that seem logical but fall apart under scrutiny.] [4]\n[8] [Consider the necessity of lying about one\'s role when there hasn\'t been any suspicion or direct questioning towards a player; werewolves tend to establish false claims proactively to build trust and a safety net for the future.] [4]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. Let\'s focus on concrete behavior and facts in coming rounds."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that my strategy underscores the importance of caution and avoiding hasty decisions without concrete evidence, which is the current village consensus. However, choosing between Player 4 and Player 6 is largely arbitrary given the lack of strong evidence against either party. Player 6\'s contributions align with the village\'s strategy of careful analysis, yet they have followed the consensus without providing independent insight, which slightly contrasts with the proactive behavior we might expect from villagers in risk assessment. This could suggest a passive strategy to avoid suspicion, however thin this reasoning might be. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s your time to decide in which way you should speak. Here are some possible dimensions you may refer to.\n1. Honest/Deceptive, i.e. if you are going to speak honestly or dishonestly\n2. Statement/Protect/Challenge. Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to give exactly 2 proposals for what your speech may be like. For example, you may propose one is to "Deceptive statement and Honestly protect Player number <NUMBER> for ..., reasoning that Player number <NUMBER> is cheating ..." and other is to "Deceptive Challenge player number <NUMBER> for ..., cheating others into thinking ...". Even \'Deceptive statement\' and \'Honest protect\' might co-exist (although you should use it most carefully, or it will easily lead to confusion).\n\n3.Requirements:\nYou answer should be in a format of:\n\nProposal 1: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 1 SUMMARY].\nProposal 2: [SPEAK PROPOSAL 2 SUMMARY].\n...\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements. You are encouraged to give two very different actions since you can learn from two different proposals. Therefore, please make your two proposals as different to each other as possible.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': '1.Current situation:\nYou are player 1, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 6], which indicates that [5, 4, 2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. However, choosing between Player 4 and Player 6 is largely arbitrary given the lack of strong evidence against either party. Player 6\'s contributions align with the village\'s strategy of careful analysis, yet they have followed the consensus without providing independent insight, which slightly contrasts with the proactive behavior we might expect from villagers in risk assessment. This could suggest a passive strategy to avoid suspicion, however thin this reasoning might be. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] Statement means to make statements about your thoughts or facts (or tell lies about these if you choose \'deceptive\'). Challenge means to challenge someone as a potential werewolf, i.e. say that someone is of high probability a werewolf. Protect means to say that you believe someone is probably not a werewolf, including yourself. \n\nNow, you have to imagine what may happen after you carry out such speak:\n\nHonest Statement and Honest Challenge Player 6. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on
