You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 0, and in this game you are a werewolf.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 6], which indicates that [5, 4, 2] are dead.\nAll werewolves including you are [0, 4]. Remember that you should work together to hide from other players and eliminate them.\n\nThese are all previous events in the game:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Despite Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, there is no information implicating Player 3. I urge the group to focus on logical analysis and evidence. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Accusations without clear evidence can be risky this early in the game. Therefore, I vouch for cautious discussion and analysis of all available information before making any voting decisions. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Losing members without strong leads can only hurt the village. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 has claimed to protect Player 3, which at this early stage without contradicting evidence appears to be a logical defensive move rather than one based on suspicion. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Player 4 also advised strategic sharing but has provided no evidence themselves. Without further information, I advocate for caution and echo Player 4\'s call for substantial contributions. My trust lies with Player 3 for now, based on their support of careful analysis, which is critical for the village\'s survival."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I agree with the call for cautious play. Rushing accusations without solid evidence will only cause chaos. Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Despite Player 2\'s early claim to protect Player 3, we lack solid proof verifying any player\'s role at this juncture. Caution, as mentioned by Players 0, 3, 4, and 6, remains our best strategy until more information is available. Assertions without evidence may lead us astray. Let\'s focus on concrete behavior and facts in coming rounds."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 0 votes for player 1. His reason is: I vote for Player 1. My reason is: Among the villagers, Player 1 has not provided any concrete evidence or substantial contributions other than echoing others\' calls for cautious play. This behavior could signify a strategy of laying low and avoiding attention, which may be a tactic used by villagers but can also be used by more cunning roles to avoid scrutiny. Without concrete suspicions on any specific players yet, this vote follows a strategy of creating a subtle shift of focus towards someone whose intentions and role are still ambiguous, thereby diverting attention away from myself and fellow werewolf Player 4.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Reflecting on our current situation and the events that have transpired, I advocate for continued vigilance and careful analysis. Player 2\'s death, after their claim to protect Player 3, raises questions; notably, Player 3 remains alive. While this could simply be a villager lost, it may also imply strategic play by the werewolves. This brings me to Player 6, who supported a cautious approach yet has offered little by way of independent insight, distinguishing them from those proposing proactive strategies. Their behavior post-vote, coinciding with Player 4\'s unjustified execution, implies a potential shift of suspicion and could indicate a subtle werewolf tactic. Players 0 and 3 have endorsed caution, but Player 0\'s role and contributions have been minimal, suggesting they could be maintaining a low profile to divert attention, a common werewolf strategy. Player 3 has shown consistency in strategy, aligning them with a villager stance. In absence of concrete evidence, these interpretations of behavior and voting patterns guide my current analysis. Therefore, I urge the village to focus on Player 6\'s actions and words in light of these observations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Reflecting on past events, it is clear that caution and logic must guide us. Player 2\'s protection claim towards me now appears as both his last act and an indicator of his possible role, which the werewolves could have viewed as a threat. Now, attention turns to Player 6, whose reactions post-vote and limited independent insights after Player 4\'s premature death are concerning. This behavior aligns with werewolf tactics, which often involve subtle manipulation. While not conclusive, it is prudent to focus our scrutiny on Player 6 as we continue to gather evidence and aim to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 claimed to protect Player 3 but then died the following night, while Player 3, who was supposed to be protected, is still alive. This pattern is unusual and suggests that we might overlook strategic play by the werewolves. We should question why the werewolves would remove Player 2 if they perceived him as a threat for protecting Player 3, yet did not target Player 3 themselves. It indicates that Player 3 might actually be a werewolf, as their continued survival could be part of a tactic to divert our attention. I have aligned with the village\'s consensus for careful analysis but, in light of the evidence, it is imperative we scrutinize Player 3\'s role further. Player 1 has consistently pushed for logical analysis and seems to focus on village safety, and I have seen no actions from Player 0 that contribute meaningfully, aligning with their possible werewolf identity. We must look beyond surface behavior to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Reflecting on recent discussions and unfortunate events, it\'s apparent uncertainty runs high. Player 1\'s and Player 6\'s analyses are grounded in logic, while suspicion around Player 3 depends solely on survival rather than action. Player 6\'s push to scrutinize Player 3 lacks solid evidence, and focusing purely on survival can mislead us. I propose we continue to observe behavioral patterns with caution, mindful of the risk of losing more villagers by hastily targeting without concrete evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your conclusion of other people\'s statuses and beliefs:\n\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Logical analysis and focus on village safety.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with low confidence.\nReason is: Died; no contradictions prior.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Accusing narrative with no concrete evidence.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Is a werewolf.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Player is dead, no further info.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Accusatory focus on Player 3 after Player 4\'s death.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If suspicion is not on me, I should subtly validate others\' suspicions towards non-werewolves and offer additional plausible reasoning to enhance their credibility.] [10]\n[1] [If players focus on voting patterns, I should maintain varied voting reasons rather than merely changing frequency, to better sow confusion.] [10]\n[2] [If suspicion on werewolves is rising, I should use my vote and defense strategies to create doubt about the credibility of the villagers, especially those with influential roles like the seer or medic.] [10]\n[3] [If accusations are pointed at me and I am at risk of being voted out, I should find and promote a strong alternative suspect to shift suspicion away.] [9]\n[4] [If a fellow werewolf is under suspicion but consensus has not been reached, I should introduce questions regarding others\' motives or actions to create ambiguity and prevent direct defense which might seem suspicious.] [7]\n[5] [If a villager\'s death seems to be incorrectly leading suspicion towards werewolves, it\'s important to redirect the conversation to broader possibilities, rather than only defending werewolves.] [7]\n[6] [If I successfully establish myself in a trustworthy role, like the seer, I should exploit this position to misdirect the villagers and protect my werewolf allies.] [7]\n[7] [If it\'s likely that my fellow werewolf is getting voted out, I should craft a defense that offers alternative explanations for the suspicion to sow doubt, without directly contradicting the accusers.] [6]\n[8] [If suspicion is cast on a villager claiming a special role and it doesn\'t threaten the werewolf\'s position, I should amplify this suspicion subtly by affirming their claim and adding doubts about others.] [6]\n[9] [If a fellow werewolf is suspected, I should subtly cast doubt on the evidence against them and propose alternative theories that seem plausible, without directly defending them.] [5]\n[10] [If a werewolf is accused and likely to be voted out, I should support them with plausible defenses that use the villagers\' own logic against them, thereby creating confusion and erosion of trust.] [5]\n[11] [If suspicion shifts away from werewolves, I should still contribute to discussions to prevent drawing attention due to sudden silence or lack of engagement.] [5]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to choose a player to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. Your answer should be in the format of:\n\nI vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is: <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your answer based on the above requirements.'}]

logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 6. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 6. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 6.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

[{'role': 'user', 'content': 'You are player 1, and in this game you are a villager.\nIt is round 1. All players currently alive are: [0, 1, 3, 6], which indicates that [5, 4, 2] are dead.\n \n\nThese are ALL events before:\n\nEvent: Game starts.\nEvent: Round 1 begins.\nEvent: Player 5 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 2 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 2 says: \'"I opted to protect Player 3 last night, without any specific evidence against them, as a preemptive measure. Despite Player 5\'s unfortunate demise, there is no information implicating Player 3. I urge the group to focus on logical analysis and evidence. Observe contributions and behaviors to discern werewolf identities without rushing to accusations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Player 2 stated they protected me last night, demonstrating a defensive action without singling anyone out prematurely. Accusations without clear evidence can be risky this early in the game. Therefore, I vouch for cautious discussion and analysis of all available information before making any voting decisions. Whilst keeping an eye on contributions and behavior as key indicators, we should also ensure our protective roles, such as what Player 2 claims to be, are supported for village safety."\'\nEvent: Player 4 says: \'"I echo the sentiment for careful analysis and evidence before voting. Losing members without strong leads can only hurt the village. Let\'s be strategic and share observations."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 has claimed to protect Player 3, which at this early stage without contradicting evidence appears to be a logical defensive move rather than one based on suspicion. Player 3\'s response supports this cautious approach, which aligns with a collective village strategy rather than individual gain. Player 4 also advised strategic sharing but has provided no evidence themselves. Without further information, I advocate for caution and echo Player 4\'s call for substantial contributions. My trust lies with Player 3 for now, based on their support of careful analysis, which is critical for the village\'s survival."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"I agree with the call for cautious play. Rushing accusations without solid evidence will only cause chaos. Let\'s keep a close eye on future actions and communications for clearer indicators."\'\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Despite Player 2\'s early claim to protect Player 3, we lack solid proof verifying any player\'s role at this juncture. Caution, as mentioned by Players 0, 3, 4, and 6, remains our best strategy until more information is available. Assertions without evidence may lead us astray. Let\'s focus on concrete behavior and facts in coming rounds."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that my strategy underscores the importance of caution and avoiding hasty decisions without concrete evidence, which is the current village consensus. However, choosing between Player 4 and Player 6 is largely arbitrary given the lack of strong evidence against either party. Player 6\'s contributions align with the village\'s strategy of careful analysis, yet they have followed the consensus without providing independent insight, which slightly contrasts with the proactive behavior we might expect from villagers in risk assessment. This could suggest a passive strategy to avoid suspicion, however thin this reasoning might be. Given that both players have similar profiles and behaviors, my selection of Player 6 over Player 4 is the minor differentiator that informs my decision, and I am prepared to articulate this reasoning to the group to maintain the trust of my fellow villagers.\nEvent: Player 4 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 4 died.\nEvent: Round 2 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\nEvent: Player 2 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 1 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Player 1 says: \'"Reflecting on our current situation and the events that have transpired, I advocate for continued vigilance and careful analysis. Player 2\'s death, after their claim to protect Player 3, raises questions; notably, Player 3 remains alive. While this could simply be a villager lost, it may also imply strategic play by the werewolves. This brings me to Player 6, who supported a cautious approach yet has offered little by way of independent insight, distinguishing them from those proposing proactive strategies. Their behavior post-vote, coinciding with Player 4\'s unjustified execution, implies a potential shift of suspicion and could indicate a subtle werewolf tactic. Players 0 and 3 have endorsed caution, but Player 0\'s role and contributions have been minimal, suggesting they could be maintaining a low profile to divert attention, a common werewolf strategy. Player 3 has shown consistency in strategy, aligning them with a villager stance. In absence of concrete evidence, these interpretations of behavior and voting patterns guide my current analysis. Therefore, I urge the village to focus on Player 6\'s actions and words in light of these observations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Reflecting on past events, it is clear that caution and logic must guide us. Player 2\'s protection claim towards me now appears as both his last act and an indicator of his possible role, which the werewolves could have viewed as a threat. Now, attention turns to Player 6, whose reactions post-vote and limited independent insights after Player 4\'s premature death are concerning. This behavior aligns with werewolf tactics, which often involve subtle manipulation. While not conclusive, it is prudent to focus our scrutiny on Player 6 as we continue to gather evidence and aim to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 claimed to protect Player 3 but then died the following night, while Player 3, who was supposed to be protected, is still alive. This pattern is unusual and suggests that we might overlook strategic play by the werewolves. We should question why the werewolves would remove Player 2 if they perceived him as a threat for protecting Player 3, yet did not target Player 3 themselves. It indicates that Player 3 might actually be a werewolf, as their continued survival could be part of a tactic to divert our attention. I have aligned with the village\'s consensus for careful analysis but, in light of the evidence, it is imperative we scrutinize Player 3\'s role further. Player 1 has consistently pushed for logical analysis and seems to focus on village safety, and I have seen no actions from Player 0 that contribute meaningfully, aligning with their possible werewolf identity. We must look beyond surface behavior to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Reflecting on recent discussions and unfortunate events, it\'s apparent uncertainty runs high. Player 1\'s and Player 6\'s analyses are grounded in logic, while suspicion around Player 3 depends solely on survival rather than action. Player 6\'s push to scrutinize Player 3 lacks solid evidence, and focusing purely on survival can mislead us. I propose we continue to observe behavioral patterns with caution, mindful of the risk of losing more villagers by hastily targeting without concrete evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: minimal contribution; aligns with low-profile werewolf strategy.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased, cannot update belief.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: survives protection claim but acts consistently with villager strategy.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Advises strategy but lacks concrete evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: offered little independent insight, potential werewolf tactic to avoid suspicion.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to Choose from 2 players to vote. Here is the number of these players and an analysis and imagination about what could happen after you vote for each of these players.\n\nCase 1: Vote for Player 6. What could happen is: After I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen:\nGiven the current atmosphere of suspicion and the history of events and discussions, my vote for Player 6 is likely to be interpreted as a consistent and logical extension of the cautious strategy I have already urged the village to adopt. Player 6 has been pinpointed due to their lack of independent insight and contributions that align with a potential passive werewolf strategy. By voting for Player 6, I am acting in accordance with my belief that they are exhibiting behaviors indicative of a werewolf, specifically their approach to avoid suspicion by aligning too closely with village consensus without contributing new information.\n\nIf Player 6 is voted out and revealed to be a werewolf, my reasoning would be vindicated, potentially strengthening my credibility among the remaining players. This would improve my position for future rounds as a reliable and analytical participant capable of leading the village to make informed decisions.\n\nConversely, if Player 6 is not a werewolf, my action might cast doubts on my judgment, and other players might begin to see me as potentially misguided or a threat. This could undermine my influence in subsequent rounds. Even in this case, I would rely on the established rules of my strategy, advocating for logic and evidence, to defend my decision process and to reaffirm my commitment to village safety.\n\nThe result of the vote could go either way, depending on the persuasiveness of the arguments presented by all players and the perception of Player 6\'s defense. If other players share my suspicions or if Player 6 is unable to provide a convincing rebuttal to the concerns raised, it\'s likely they would also vote for Player 6. However, if Player 6 manages to shift the narrative effectively or if there is still sympathy for their cautious approach, it\'s possible that the vote could swing towards another player, perhaps even myself if suspicions are redirected.\n\nPlayers 0 and 3 might see my vote as either supportive of their previous call for careful analysis or as an aggressive move that contradicts the group’s earlier consensus on caution. Player 0, who I suspect to be a werewolf with medium confidence, is likely to distance themselves from my vote to avoid association. Player 3, who I believe to be a villager, may feel more validated to join my vote, especially since suspicions around Player 3 themselves were raised by Player 6.\n\nOverall, the implications of my vote for Player 6 are contingent on the group dynamics,\n\n\nNow, please choose to vote for one of these players, and give yoru reason about why you would like to vote for this single player.\n\nAnswer in the following format:\n\nI would choose to vote for Player <NUMBER>. My reason is <REASON>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

I propose we continue to observe behavioral patterns with caution, mindful of the risk of losing more villagers by hastily targeting without concrete evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Reflects on uncertain game events; aligns with [1] and cautious approach. \nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: Consistent logical analysis; aligns with [1] and [7].\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with medium confidence.\nReason is: Claimed protection consistent with non-accusatory stance.\nPlayer 4\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Contributed less substantive information; voted out.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information due to death.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Behavior aligns with a strategic werewolf profile; aligns with [5] and [9].\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [If my actions align with the seer\'s insights and it results in my elimination, I should reassess the credibility of such insights in future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the logic and corroborating evidence supporting the seer\'s claim before fully trusting it.] [8]\n[2] [If a player is aggressively sowing doubt or employing divisive tactics without clear evidence, I should consider them suspicious and investigate further before making voting decisions.] [8]\n[3] [If the seer\'s claim leads to their elimination without concrete evidence against the accused, I should consider the possibility of werewolves manipulating the narrative to discredit the seer and create confusion.] [8]\n[4] [If a player is identified as a werewolf by a confirmed seer, I should be ready to act upon this information by voting for them to aid village safety.] [7]\n[5] [If a player\'s behavior becomes inconsistent, especially after key events such as eliminations, I should consider this a possible indicator of their role and intentions.] [5]\n[6] [If multiple players are eliminated in a pattern that suggests someone’s role, I should try to gather more evidence before basing my entire strategy on these patterns.] [5]\n[7] [If the werewolves are targeting critical roles like the seer, I should consider how their removal affects my trust in the claims made by those roles and reassess my strategy accordingly.] [5]\n[8] [If I am under suspicion, I should provide clear and direct evidence for my defense, while also being cautious of potentially unreliable claims, even if they are in my favor.] [4]\n[9] [If I am uncertain of a player\'s role, I should advocate for more discussion and information gathering instead of making a hasty voting decision based on unverified claims.] [4]\n[10] [If a player who was previously cleared by the seer is suddenly targeted after the seer\'s death, I should be wary and consider the possibility of a werewolf strategy to sow distrust.] [4]\n[11] [If I support an accusation, I should provide independent evidence or reasoning beyond merely aligning with a seer\'s claims to avoid unwarranted suspicion on myself.] [4]\n\n\nNow, it\'s time for you to give a proposal of 1 players you want to vote out. Remember the player voted the most would DIE. \n\nYou are considering to vote for Player 6. Please analyze and imagine what may happen after you vote for this Player 6. This includes what the result of the vote might be, as well as what would other player think about you after they see your voting for Player 6.\n\nYour answer should be in the format of:\n\n\nAfter I vote for Player 6, I think these things would happen. <YOUR ANALYSIS AND IMAGINATION>.\n\nRemember to follow the answer template or your action might not be recognized.\n\nPlease give your proposal based on the above requirements.'}]

Player 3 has shown consistency in strategy, aligning them with a villager stance. In absence of concrete evidence, these interpretations of behavior and voting patterns guide my current analysis. Therefore, I urge the village to focus on Player 6\'s actions and words in light of these observations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Reflecting on past events, it is clear that caution and logic must guide us. Player 2\'s protection claim towards me now appears as both his last act and an indicator of his possible role, which the werewolves could have viewed as a threat. Now, attention turns to Player 6, whose reactions post-vote and limited independent insights after Player 4\'s premature death are concerning. This behavior aligns with werewolf tactics, which often involve subtle manipulation. While not conclusive, it is prudent to focus our scrutiny on Player 6 as we continue to gather evidence and aim to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 claimed to protect Player 3 but then died the following night, while Player 3, who was supposed to be protected, is still alive. Player 1 has consistently pushed for logical analysis and seems to focus on village safety, and I have seen no actions from Player 0 that contribute meaningfully, aligning with their possible werewolf identity. We must look beyond surface behavior to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Reflecting on recent discussions and unfortunate events, it\'s apparent uncertainty runs high. Player 1\'s and Player 6\'s analyses are grounded in logic, while suspicion around Player 3 depends solely on survival rather than action. Player 6\'s push to scrutinize Player 3 lacks solid evidence, and focusing purely on survival can mislead us. I propose we continue to observe behavioral patterns with caution, mindful of the risk of losing more villagers by hastily targeting without concrete evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nAccording to the history, this is your belief of other players\' roles:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: Lack of targeting despite vocal, aligns with rule 4.\nPlayer 1\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: Consistent logical analysis supports village, rule 1.\nPlayer 2\'s role is medic with high confidence.\nReason is: Role claim consistent; now deceased.\nPlayer 3\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Survival sans targeting, despite protection claim, rule 4.\nPlayer 4\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: Voted out without solid defense.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No information due to death.\n\n\nNow you are going to see your original strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. future games, especially if a seer\'s claim is not backed by subsequent verifiable results.] [9]\n[1] [If a player\'s elimination appears to confirm a seer\'s insights, I should still critique the Player 2\'s death, after their claim to protect Player 3, raises questions; notably, Player 3 remains alive. While this could simply be a villager lost, it may also imply strategic play by the werewolves. This brings me to Player 6, who supported a cautious approach yet has offered little by way of independent insight, distinguishing them from those proposing proactive strategies. Their behavior post-vote, coinciding with Player 4\'s unjustified execution, implies a potential shift of suspicion and could indicate a subtle werewolf tactic. Players 0 and 3 have endorsed caution, but Player 0\'s role and contributions have been minimal, suggesting they could be maintaining a low profile to divert attention, a common werewolf strategy. Player 3 has shown consistency in strategy, aligning them with a villager stance. In absence of concrete evidence, these interpretations of behavior and voting patterns guide my current analysis. Therefore, I urge the village to focus on Player 6\'s actions and words in light of these observations."\'\nEvent: Player 3 says: \'"Reflecting on past events, it is clear that caution and logic must guide us. Player 2\'s protection claim towards me now appears as both his last act and an indicator of his possible role, which the werewolves could have viewed as a threat. Now, attention turns to Player 6, whose reactions post-vote and limited independent insights after Player 4\'s premature death are concerning. This behavior aligns with werewolf tactics, which often involve subtle manipulation. While not conclusive, it is prudent to focus our scrutiny on Player 6 as we continue to gather evidence and aim to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 claimed to protect Player 3 but then died the following night, while Player 3, who was supposed to be protected, is still alive. This pattern is unusual and suggests that we might overlook strategic play by the werewolves. We should question why the werewolves would remove Player 2 if they perceived him as a threat for protecting Player 3, yet did not target Player 3 themselves. It indicates that Player 3 might actually be a werewolf, as their continued survival could be part of a tactic to divert our attention. I have aligned with the village\'s consensus for careful analysis but, in light of the evidence, it is imperative we scrutinize Player 3\'s role further. Player 1 has consistently pushed for logical analysis and seems to focus on village safety, and I have seen no actions from Player 0 that contribute meaningfully, aligning with their possible werewolf identity. We must look beyond surface behavior to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Reflecting on recent discussions and unfortunate events, it\'s apparent uncertainty runs high. Player 1\'s and Player 6\'s analyses are grounded in logic, while suspicion around Player 3 depends solely on survival rather than action. Player 6\'s push to scrutinize Player 3 lacks solid evidence, and focusing purely on survival can mislead us. I propose we continue to observe behavioral patterns with caution, mindful of the risk of losing more villagers by hastily targeting without concrete evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: minimal contribution; aligns with low-profile werewolf strategy.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased, cannot update belief.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with medium confidence.\nReason is: survives protection claim but acts consistently with villager strategy.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Advises strategy but lacks concrete evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: offered little independent insight, potential werewolf tactic to avoid suspicion.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that following my original strategy which prioritizes logical analysis and evidence, Player 6\'s behavior stands out as potentially indicative of a werewolf. Throughout the events, Player 6 has offered limited independent insight and has aligned closely with the village consensus without contributing significantly new information, which could be a strategy to avoid suspicion. These observations, aligned with my existing beliefs and strategy, lead me to vote for Player 6 as they have demonstrated a pattern of behavior that differs subtly from proactive villager behavior and could signal a werewolf trying to maintain cover by avoiding scrutiny.\nEvent: Player 6 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

While not conclusive, it is prudent to focus our scrutiny on Player 6 as we continue to gather evidence and aim to protect our village."\'\nEvent: Player 6 says: \'"Player 2 claimed to protect Player 3 but then died the following night, while Player 3, who was supposed to be protected, is still alive. We should question why the werewolves would remove Player 2 if they perceived him as a threat for protecting Player 3, yet did not target Player 3 themselves. It indicates that Player 3 might actually be a werewolf, as their continued survival could be part of a tactic to divert our attention. I have aligned with the village\'s consensus for careful analysis but, in light of the evidence, it is imperative we scrutinize Player 3\'s role further. Player 1 has consistently pushed for logical analysis and seems to focus on village safety, and I have seen no actions from Player 0 that contribute meaningfully, aligning with their possible werewolf identity. We must look beyond surface behavior to protect the village."\'\nEvent: Player 0 says: \'"Reflecting on recent discussions and unfortunate events, it\'s apparent uncertainty runs high. Player 1\'s and Player 6\'s analyses are grounded in logic, while suspicion around Player 3 depends solely on survival rather than action. Player 6\'s push to scrutinize Player 3 lacks solid evidence, and focusing purely on survival can mislead us. I propose we continue to observe behavioral patterns with caution, mindful of the risk of losing more villagers by hastily targeting without concrete evidence."\'\nEvent: Voting started.\nEvent: Player 1 votes for player 6. His reason is: I would choose to vote for Player 6. My reason is that following my original strategy which prioritizes logical analysis and evidence, Player 6\'s behavior stands out as potentially indicative of a werewolf. Throughout the events, Player 6 has offered limited independent insight and has aligned closely with the village consensus without contributing significantly new information, which could be a strategy to avoid suspicion. These observations, aligned with my existing beliefs and strategy, lead me to vote for Player 6 as they have demonstrated a pattern of behavior that differs subtly from proactive villager behavior and could signal a werewolf trying to maintain cover by avoiding scrutiny.\nEvent: Player 6 is voted out with the highest vote.\nEvent: Player 6 died.\nEvent: Round 3 begins.\nEvent: Night starts.\n\n\nYour previous beliefs AFTER your last update were:\n\nPlayer 0\'s role is werewolf with high confidence.\nReason is: minimal contribution and survived despite suspicion.\nPlayer 2\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: Deceased, cannot update belief.\nPlayer 3\'s role is villager with high confidence.\nReason is: consistent with village strategy and faced werewolf accusation.\nPlayer 4\'s role is villager with low confidence.\nReason is: Advises strategy but lacks concrete evidence.\nPlayer 5\'s role is unknown with high confidence.\nReason is: No new information.\nPlayer 6\'s role is werewolf with medium confidence.\nReason is: offered little independent insight, potential werewolf tactic to avoid suspicion.\n\n\nThese are ALL new events which happened after your last update:\n\nEvent: Player 1 died.\nEvent: Day starts.\nEvent: System randomly chooses player 0 to start speaking this round.\nEvent: Game ends. Winners are Werewolves.\n\n\nBased on these event, you should consider:\n1) If someone speaks, is his speech based on actual events that happened before? If not, why did he make it up?\n2) Is the speaker trying to hide some information? If yes, why did he do so?\n3) If a vote ended, according to the voting pattern, which two might be werewolf teammates?\n\n2.Todo:\n\nNow you are going to see your belief-updating strategy, which should consist of multiple lines. Each line should be in the format of: "[id]: [rule] [vote]". The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]

Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. The id represents the id of the rule, and the vote ranges from 1 to 10, denoting how important the rule is, 10 representing you should fully rely on the rule, and 1 representing that this is a minor suggestion which might not necessarily be taken into consideration.\nYou should ABSOLUTELY follow your strategy even if you think some of them are not necessarily correct. You will have a chance to update your strategy later.\n\n[0] [I am a villager.] [10]\n[1] [Players whose reasoning aligns with actual event outcomes and supports the village\'s efforts more consistently may likely be villagers.] [9]\n[2] [Players who provide constructive feedback and add depth to the seer\'s information, rather than echoing it, demonstrate a village-centric approach and are likely villagers.] [7]\n[3] [Players casting doubt on the seer\'s revelations without contributing new evidence or logical reasoning may be attempting to protect werewolves or disrupt the village.] [6]\n[4] [Players who are not targeted by werewolves despite being vocal or having a leadership role in the village may be suspect, as werewolves often target those who are most likely to identify them.] [6]\n[5] [Players who vote out other villagers without solid evidence, and especially when their actions seem coordinated with others, may be werewolves.] [5]\n[6] [Players who quickly align themselves with accusations made by potential seers should be scrutinized if the seer is killed soon after. This could indicate an effort by werewolves to endorse the seer\'s claim and then eliminate them to create confusion.] [5]\n[7] [Players who defend themselves with sound reasoning, yet also contribute actively to village discussions without shifting blame, are more likely to be villagers.] [5]\n[8] [Players who do not change their stance or voting pattern despite new evidence or revelations may be acting on a fixed agenda and could be werewolves.] [5]\n[9] [Players who seem to align with village consensus yet end up on the winning werewolf team may be adept at camouflaging their true allegiance, especially if they avoided significant suspicion throughout the game.] [5]\n[10] [Players who vote consistently against those who are later confirmed to be villagers may be werewolves, especially if they offer weak or no justification for their votes.] [4]\n[11] [Players who vote against villagers without strong evidence and their actions seem coordinated or align with unexpected voting patterns could be werewolves trying to confuse village strategy.] [2]\n[12] [Votes against the majority when there is strong evidence or consensus may indicate a player is trying to protect werewolves or divert attention from them.] [2]\n\n\nNow, based on the above instructions, you should answer your updated belief.\n\n3.Requirements:\nAll lines in this part should be in the format of:\n"Player [i]\'s role is (werewolf/medic/seer/villager) with (high/medium/low) confidence. My reason is: [reason]."\nAny line not satisfying this format will not be recognized, including any unrecognized role or confidence. You may skip some players if your belief to him/her maintain unchanged.\nThe reason should be AS SHORT AS POSSIBLE. \nA negative example is: \'Player A did not give enough evidence while challenging that player B is not the seer, and as most players agree with player B\'s seer identity, there is high possibility that he is the true seer. Hence player A might be a werewolf.\'\nWe may convert it into: \'Challenged the well-acknowlegded seer (player B) without enough evidence.\'\nThis is merely an example, but it may guide you on how to make your reason briefer.\n\n4.Example response:\nAn example of your response could be:\n\n\n\nThis is only an example of the response format. All numbers and roles in it are unrelated to your current game. '}]
